title: Roberts v. LaConey
description: In this opinion, the Court adopts the Special Referee's finding that respondent has engaged in the unauthorized practice of law.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Eddie Roberts, Petitioner,
				v.
				Glen LaConey, d/b/a Refunds Plus, Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No. 26376
Submitted August 14, 2007 - Filed September 4, 2007Â  

IN THE ORIGINAL JURISDICTION


	
		
			
				Harry Clayton DePew, Law Office of Harry DePew, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Glen K. LaConey, Refunds Plus, of Columbia, for Respondent.
				H. Clayton Walker, Jr., and Robert L. Reibold, of Walker & Reibold, of Columbia, for Bridgewood Homes, Inc., Amicus Curiae.
				
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  We accepted this declaratory judgment matter in our original jurisdiction, pursuant to In re Unauthorized Practice of Law Rules Proposed by the South Carolina Bar, 309 S.C. 304, 422 S.E.2d 123 (1992), to determine if respondent has engaged in the unauthorized practice of law.Â  We also granted a motion for leave to file an amicus brief filed by Bridgewood Homes, Inc.Â  The matter was referred to a Special Referee, by order dated May 17, 2005, to take evidence and issue a report containing proposed findings of fact and recommendations to the Court.

The Special Referee issued a Report of Proposed Findings of Fact and Conclusions of Law recommending this Court find respondent engaged in the unauthorized practice of law.Â  Thereafter, respondent was the only party to file exceptions to the Report.Â  A schedule for serving and filing the briefs and record in this matter was established.Â  However, respondent failed to serve and file a record or brief as instructed.Â 
 
Rule 208(a)(4), SCACR, states that if an appellant fails to file a brief, the appeal will be dismissed.Â  Because respondent is the party objecting to the Special Refereeâ€™s report by way of exceptions, and was instructed to serve and file the record and a brief addressing the exceptions, he is in the posture of an appellant.Â  Accordingly, because he has failed to file a brief in the matter, we hereby dismiss his exceptions and, because we agree that respondent has engaged in the unauthorized practice of law, we adopt the following Report of the Special Referee as the opinion of this Court.
 
SPECIAL REFEREEâ€™S REPORT OF PROPOSED FINDINGS OF FACT AND CONCLUSIONS OF LAW
This case was filed in the original jurisdiction of the Supreme Court of South Carolina.Â  The Court appointed me as a special referee to take evidence and issue a report containing proposed findings of fact and recommendations concerning Petitionerâ€™s allegations that the Respondent has engaged in the unauthorized practice of law.
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Petitionerâ€™s Allegations
The allegations turn on a document titled â€œNotice of Assignment and Assignment of Judgment,â€ which Petitioner contends is essentially a contingency fee agreement for legal services, in which Respondent agreed to attempt to collect a judgment in exchange for a fee of approximately one-third.Â  Petitioner contends that, under the terms of this agreement, Respondent engaged in the unauthorized practice of law in attempting to collect the judgment.Â 
 

II.Â Â Â Â Â  Proposed Findings of Fact
On January 3, 1996, Paul W. Nickoson[] obtained a judgment in the amount of $7587.67 against Eddie Roberts, d/b/a Eddie Roberts Auto Service.Â  Respondent approached Nickoson about attempting to collect this judgment.[1]Â  On August 17, 2004, Nickoson and Respondent executed a document entitled â€œNotice of Assignment and Assignment of Judgment.â€Â  The document provides in important part:

	I, Paul W. Nickoson, Judgment Creditor in the above entitled actions, (hereinafter â€œAssignorâ€), do hereby transfer, assign and setover the Judgment rendered to me in this action to REFUNDS PLUS . . . (hereinafter â€œAssigneeâ€) in exchange for a retention of a (66.6%) interest in the amount recovered by Assignee.
	***
	Assignee, itâ€™s agents, assigns and successors shall have full authority to settle, compromise and enforce said Judgment, and Assignor withdraws all right to same.

(Reference to exhibits omitted).
On August 27, 2004, Respondent began the process of execution of the judgment by having the Richland County Clerk of Court command the Sheriff of Richland County to satisfy the judgment out of the personal or real property of Roberts. . . .Â  Respondent signed the Execution Against Property as â€œPlaintiffâ€™s Attorneys.â€

On September 2, 2004, Respondent wrote a letter to Roberts explaining that he was going to begin efforts to collect the judgment that he claimed had been â€œassignedâ€ to him.Â  (Reference to exhibit omitted).Â  In this letter, Respondent explains the manner in which he planned to collect the judgment, including the manner in which he planned to use the judicial process.Â  Specifically, Respondent stated his intention to file an action in the â€œMaster-in-Equity Court to Order you to appear with your . . . financial records . . . and testify under oath . . . .â€Â  Respondent offered several legal opinions in the letter, including that a corporation Roberts apparently owned â€œwould be held jointly and severably liable for this debt.â€Â  He also made several threats about consequences Roberts would face if he did not cooperate and willingly satisfy the judgment.[2]Â   
On September 17, 2004, Respondent served â€œPlaintiffâ€™s Request for Production of Documentsâ€ on Roberts, with an attached â€œExhibit Aâ€ listing seventeen categories of documents Roberts was required to produce.Â  (Reference to exhibit omitted).Â  Respondent amended the Request for Production on September 18, 2004.Â  (Reference to exhibit omitted).Â  On September 29, 2004, Respondent again wrote Roberts making additional threats about how he would use the judicial process and the consequences Roberts would face if he did not pay the judgment.Â  (Reference to exhibit omitted).
On February 8, 2005, Respondent filed a â€œNotice of Motion and Motion for Supplementary Proceedings.â€Â  (Reference to exhibit omitted).Â  This motion resulted in an â€œOrder of Reference and Rule to Show Causeâ€ signed on February 15, requiring Roberts to attend a hearing and bring all his financial records.Â  The Honorable Joseph Strickland, Master in Equity for Richland County, held a hearing sometime later and Respondent personally appeared as the representative of the judgment holder.Â  Finally, on February 28, 2005, Respondent wrote Roberts again threatening consequences of not claiming mail sent to Roberts, and threatening to â€œhave you ARRESTED and brought to court in restraints the way Moses was brought before Pharoah in the movie, â€˜The Ten commandments.â€™â€
III.Â Â Â Â  Applicable Law
â€œThe generally understood definition of the practice of law embraces the preparation of pleadings, and other papers incident to actions and special proceedings, and the management of such actions and proceedings on behalf of clients before judges and courts.â€Â  Brown v. Coe, 365 S.C. 137, 139, 616 S.E.2d 705, 706-07 (2005)(citing Doe v. McMaster, 355 S.C. 306, 311, 585 S.E.2d 773, 775-77 (2003); State v. Despain, 319 S.C. 317, 319 460 S.E.2d 576, 577 (1995); In re Duncan, 83 S.C. 186, 189, 65 S.E. 210, 211 (1909)).Â  â€œThe practice of law â€˜is not confined to litigation, but extends to activities in other fields which entail specialized legal knowledge and ability.â€™â€Â  Linder v. Insurance Claims Consultants, Inc., 348 S.C. 477, 487, 560 S.E.2d 612, 617 (2002) (quoting State v. Buyers Services Co., Inc., 292 S.C. 426, 430, 357 S.E.2d 15, 17 (1987)).Â  Other than these general statements, there is no comprehensive definition of the practice of law.Â  See Linder, 348 S.C. at 487, 560 S.E.2d at 617-18.Â  Rather, what constitutes the practice of law must be decided on the facts and in the context of each individual case.
IV.Â Â Â Â  Proposed Conclusions of Law
The â€œNotice of Assignment and Assignment of Judgmentâ€ is not an assignment of the judgment as it purports to be.Â  The original judgment holder retained an ownership interest in the judgment.Â  Respondent gained an interest that had value only on the successful collection of some portion of it.Â  Respondent paid nothing for the interest he acquired.Â  He was to be paid, if at all, only when the judgment was collected.Â  The practical effect of their agreement is that Respondent was to be paid a fee to collect the debt.Â  Therefore, the supposed â€œassignee,â€ Respondent, was not acting entirely on his own behalf, but on behalf of the original judgment holder.Â  Respondent could not have been practicing law if he had been acting on his own behalf under a true assignment.Â  However, because he was acting on behalf of the original judgment holder, his actions must be examined to determine whether they constitute the practice of law.Â 
 
Respondent did many things on behalf of the judgment holder in the collection of this debt that meet the general definition of the practice of law.Â  He prepared â€œpleadings, and other papers incident to actions and special proceedings.â€Â  See Brown, 365 S.C. at 139, 616 S.E.2d at 706-07.Â  These include â€œPlaintiffâ€™s Request for Production of Documents,â€ the â€œNotice of Motion and Motion for Supplementary Proceedings,â€ and the â€œExecution Against Judgment.â€
Respondent also managed the collection action â€œon behalf of [the judgment holder] before judges and courts.â€Â  
See Id.  For example, Respondent prepared â€œExecution Against Judgmentâ€ 
and had it signed by the Clerk of the Circuit Court directing the Sheriff to 
satisfy the judgment.  His â€œmanagementâ€ activities also include serving the 
Request for Production on Roberts, and filing the Motion he prepared in the 
Equity Division of the Circuit Court.  He used the â€œMotionâ€ to obtain an 
â€œOrder of Reference and Rule to Show Cause.â€  Most importantly, he appeared 
at a hearing before the Equity Division on behalf of the judgment holder.
In addition, Respondent developed a strategy to use in collecting the debt for Nickoson.Â  In furtherance of this strategy, he sent letters to Roberts that were designed to induce him to pay the judgment.Â  Some of these letters contained legal opinions formulated by Respondent.Â  This is the type of strategic activity which the Supreme Court referred to in Linder as entailing â€œspecialized legal knowledge and ability.â€Â  348 S.C. at 487, 560 S.E.2d at 617.
Finally, in determining whether someone is practicing law, it is important to consider representations the person makes about his own activity.Â  As mentioned above, Respondent represented on the signature line of the â€œExecution Against Judgmentâ€ that he was acting as â€œPlaintiffâ€™s Attorneys.â€Â  Despite the fact that this language appears to be part of the printed form Respondent was using, by signing the form as he did, Respondent made a public statement as to the role he was playing in collecting the judgment.Â  The use of this language in a document being served on a judgment debtor is reasonably understood to increase the chances of collecting the debt.
Other states have considered whether similar activity constitutes the unauthorized practice of law.Â  In Iowa Supreme Court Commâ€™n on Unauthorized Practice of Law v. A-1 Assocs, Ltd., 623 N.W.2d 803 (2001), the Supreme Court of Iowa concluded that an instrument similar to the â€œNotice of Assignment and Assignment of Judgmentâ€ used by Respondent was not in fact an assignment of a judgment, but was an agreement for collection services such as a lawyer would perform.Â  The court noted that if the instrument truly had been an assignment, then the assignee could have attempted to collect the judgment without engaging in the practice of law.Â  The court went on to state â€œA-1â€™s claimed status as a bona fide assignee is defeated under this record, however, because the assignment - though absolute in form - is, in fact, a transfer intended primarily to secure payment for services rendered.Â  (citation omitted).Â  This is demonstrated by the fact that A-1 pays nothing for the purported â€˜assignment.â€™ . . .Â  Courts throughout the country have condemned this practice as an attempt by collection agencies to accomplish indirectly what the law otherwise prohibits.â€Â  (citation omitted).Â  623 N.W.2d at 808.Â  The court concluded that A-1 Associated, Ltd. had engaged in the unauthorized practice of law.Â  â€œSo long as A-1 is not representing its own legal interests . . ., but the legal interests of others, it is engaging - without license or other authorization - in the practice of law.â€Â  623 N.W.2d at 808-09.
In State ex rel. State Bar of Wisconsin v. Bonded Collections, Inc., 36 Wis.2d 643, 154 N.W.2d 250 (1967),[3] the Supreme Court of Wisconsin considered the following issue:Â  â€œDoes a course of conduct whereby a collection agency takes assignments of accounts for collection, . . ., brings suit in its own name, and then pursuant to a prior agreement deducts from the proceeds, costs, and a fixed percentage as its fee and remits the balance to the creditor, constitute the unauthorized practice of law?â€Â  154 N.W.2d at 253-54.Â  In concluding that it does, the court stated â€œ[i]t is sheer hypocrisy to conclude that the percentage retained by the collection agency represents its equity or ownership share of the claim.Â  It is its fee or charge for professional services rendered.â€Â  154 N.W.2d at 256.Â  The Wisconsin court also noted that â€œ[t]he collection agency by going into court representing itself as the client perpetrates a fraud on the court.â€Â  Id.
See also State ex rel. Norvell v. Credit Bureau of Albuquerque, Inc., 85 N.M. 521, 514 P.2d 40, 49 (1973) (assignments procured by credit bureau not truly taken to acquire title and ownership but to facilitate delivery of legal services for consideration constitute unauthorized practice of law); State ex rel. Frieson v. Isner, 168 W.Va.758, 285 S.E.2d 641, 651-52 (1981) (citing numerous cases to support conclusion that assignment taken solely to maintain suit on creditorâ€™s claim is sham perpetrated on court to enable unauthorized practice of law).
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we conclude respondentâ€™s actions, as outlined in this matter, constitute the unauthorized practice of law.
JUDGMENT DECLARED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] It was not possible for the Special Referee to determine the precise manner in which Respondent solicited the opportunity to collect this judgment, because Respondent chose not to show up for the hearing.Â  However, it is clear from the evidence that was presented that respondent solicited the business of collecting this and other judgments.Â  This evidence includes the fact that Respondent operated under the business name of Refunds Plus.
[2] Many of these threats are entirely inappropriate, and would violate the Rules of Professional Conduct if made by a lawyer.Â  However, this aspect of Respondentâ€™s conduct is not before me.
[3] In this case, the collection agency actually hired a lawyer to represent it in court.Â  The basis of the courtâ€™s decision, however, was that the collection agency was practicing law by representing the creditor, and the fact that the agency hired a lawyer to do so did not change that.

title: Callahan v. Beaufort County School District
description: The Court holds that S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-560 sets forth strict requirements that must be met in order for a claimant to pursue a workersâ€™ compensation action and a third-party suit.  However, the Claimant in this case was not barred from pursing workersâ€™ compensation benefits because she voluntarily dismissed her third-party suit.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Christine Callahan, Employee, Respondent,
				v.
				Beaufort County School District, Employer, and S.C. School Boards Insurance Trust, Carrier, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Curtis L. Coltrane, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26377
Heard May 22, 2007 - Filed September 4, 2007Â Â  

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


	
		
			
				Kirsten L. Barr, of Trask & Howell, of Mt. Pleasant, for Appellants.
				William B. Harvey, III, of Harvey & Battey, of Beaufort, for Respondent.
			
		
	

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â Â Â Â Â Â  This is a workersâ€™ compensation appeal.Â  The single commissioner denied workersâ€™ compensation benefits due to the claimantâ€™s failure to provide notice of her third-party suit as required by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-560(b) (1985).Â  The full commission affirmed, and claimant appealed to the circuit court.Â  The circuit court reversed, holding that the lack of notice had not prevented the â€œequitable adjustment of the rights of all the partiesâ€ because the third-party suit never reached a final determination on the merits.Â  Beaufort County School District (â€œEmployerâ€) appealed, and we certified the appeal pursuant to Rule 204, SCACR.Â  We affirm as modified.
FACTS
Christine Callahan (â€œClaimantâ€) alleged injuries due to exposure to chemicals at Battery Creek High School on November 14, 2002.Â  Employer and the South Carolina School Boards Insurance Trust (â€œCarrierâ€) denied workersâ€™ compensation benefits.Â  Claimant filed a Form 50 on January 17, 2003, to request a hearing.
On January 24, 2003, Claimant filed a civil action against a third-party, Tech Clean Industries, based on the same injuries alleged in the workersâ€™ compensation action.Â  However, it was not until July 16, 2003, that the Claimant filed and served a Form S-2, providing the Commission, Employer, and Carrier with notice of her intent to pursue both a workersâ€™ compensation claim and a third-party civil action for the same injuries.Â  Claimant voluntarily dismissed the third-party action without prejudice in November 2003.[1]
ISSUE
Did the circuit court err by failing to find Claimantâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation claim is barred because she did not provide notice of her third-party action within thirty days of its commencement, in accordance with the requirements of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-560(b)?
ANALYSIS
Review of a decision of the workersâ€™ compensation commission is governed by the Administrative Procedures Act.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 276 S.E.2d 304 (1981).Â  We may reverse where the decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5)(d) (Supp. 2006).Â  
 
South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-560 sets forth the requirements for simultaneously pursuing a third-party action and a workersâ€™ compensation claim.Â  The statute provides:

	Notice of the commencement of the [third-party] action shall be given within thirty days thereafter to the [Commission], the employer and carrier upon a form prescribed by the [Commission].

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-560(b).Â  An injured party may proceed against both the employer-carrier and against a third-party tortfeasor by complying with the requirements of Â§ 42-1-560.Â  Fisher v. S.C. Dept. of Mental Retardation-Coastal Center, 277 S.C. 573, 575, 291 S.E.2d 200, 201 (1982); Hudson v. Townsend Saw Chain Co., 296 S.C. 17, 20, 370 S.E.2d 104, 106 (Ct. App. 1998) (â€œ[subsection (b)] plainly requires an employee, when he or she brings a third-party action, to give notice to the Commission, the employer, and the employerâ€™s carrier of the commencement of the third-party action within 30 days of its commencement.â€).
In this case, Claimant did not provide the Form S-2 to the Commission, Employer, and Carrier until July 2003, nearly six months after she initially filed her third-party suit and three months after the action had been removed to federal court.Â 
 
Because workersâ€™ compensation statutes provide an exclusive compensatory system in derogation of common law rights, we strictly construe the requirements of Â§ 42-1-560 and leave it to the legislature to amend and define its ambiguities.Â  Cf. Wigfall v. Tideland Util., Inc., 354 S.C. 100, 110, 580 S.E.2d 100, 105 (2003).Â  Here, the statute clearly requires timely notice to be given to all three entities- employer, carrier, and Commission- on the Form S-2.[2]
We find the circuit court erred by excusing compliance with the statute based on the â€œequitable adjustment of the rights of all the parties.â€Â  Even though the employer had not lost its right of subrogation against the potentially responsible third-party, the statutory provision mandates notice to the employer, carrier, and Commission within thirty days of filing the third-party suit.Â  It was improper for the circuit court to conduct an equity analysis to carve an exception to the workersâ€™ compensation notice requirement.Â  See Wigfall, supra; Santee Cooper Resort, Inc. v. S.C. Pub. Serv. Commn, 298 S.C. 179, 185, 379 S.E.2d 119, 123 (1989) (holding that a courtâ€™s equitable powers must yield in the face of an unambiguously worded statute).
Despite Claimantâ€™s failure to comply with Â§ 42-1-560, we nonetheless affirm the circuit courtâ€™s finding that her workersâ€™ compensation claim may proceed.Â  In this case, Claimant voluntarily dismissed her third-party suit pursuant to Rule 41, FRCP.Â  A voluntary dismissal leaves the situation as though no suit had ever been filed.Â  9 Wright & Miller, Federal Practice & Procedure 2d Â§ 2367, at 321 (1995); Allen v. S. Ry. Co., 218 S.C. 291, 297-298, 62 S.E.2d 507, 511 (1950).Â  Following this rule, the third-party suit originally filed in January 2003 became a nullity, and Â§ 42-1-560 is not applicable.Â  As a result, there is no violation of Â§ 42-1-560 when the third-party suit is treated as never being filed.
CONCLUSION
We hold that Â§ 42-1-560(b) must be strictly followed in order for a claimant to preserve her right to proceed against both an employer and a third-party.Â  On the facts before us, Claimantâ€™s voluntary dismissal without prejudice of her third-party suit allows her to proceed with her workersâ€™ compensation claim.Â  Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court is
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT, JJ., and Acting Justice R. Ferrell Cothran, Jr., concur.Â Â Â Â Â Â  
 

[1] Although it is unclear from the record whether Claimant re-filed the third-party action, the Court was made aware at oral argument that Claimant later re-filed the third-party action against Tech Clean.Â  We offer no opinion on the efficacy of this re-filing.
[2] This holding does not conflict with our past cases.Â  This Court previously held that a claimant had elected a remedy, thus forgoing workersâ€™ compensation benefits, by settling a third-party claim without complying with the notice requirements of Â§ 42-1-560, even though the carrier had actual knowledge of the third-party suit.Â  Fisher, supra; see also Hardee v. Bruce Johnson Trucking Co., 293 S.C. 349, 354-355, 360 S.E.2d 522, 525 (Ct. App. 1987)(discussing the facts of Fisher).Â  Additionally, prior cases interpreting this statute have found that prejudice should not be considered.Â  See Hudson, supra (finding claimantâ€™s prejudice argument â€œunpersuasive, if in fact the question of prejudice is relevant at allâ€)(citing Stroy v. Millwood Drug Store, 235 S.C. 52, 109 S.E.2d 706 (1959)); Kimmer v. Murata, 372 S.C. 39, 640 S.E.2d 507 (Ct. App. 2006)(holding that â€œprejudice is â€˜NOTâ€™ an element to be considered in regard to the failure to give mandated statutory notice.â€).

title: In the Matter of McBee, Bethune, and Lynchburg Municipal Court Judge Fred D. Stephens
description: This is a judicial disciplinary opinion in which the Court issued a public reprimand.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        In the Matter of McBee, Bethune,
          and Lynchburg Municipal Court Judge Fred D. Stephens, Respondent. 
		 
      
    
  


Opinion No.Â  26378
Submitted August 22, 2007 - Filed September 10, 2007Â   

PUBLIC REPRIMAND


  
    
      
        Lesley M.
          Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Senior Disciplinary
          Counsel, and Robert E. Bogan, Assistant Deputy Attorney General, all of
          Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.  
        William
          S. Tetterton, of Camden, for respondent.Â Â   
      
    
  


PER
  CURIAM:Â  In this judicial disciplinary
  matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered
  into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent (Agreement) pursuant to Rule 21,
  RJDE, Rule 502, SCACR.Â  In the Agreement, respondent admits misconduct and
  consents to the imposition of a public reprimand pursuant to Rule 7(b), RJDE,
  Rule 502, SCACR.[1]Â 
The facts as set forth in the Agreement are as follows.Â   
FACTS
On June 14, 2006, while serving as
  a judge for the Town of McBee, respondent was indicted by the State Grand Jury
  of South Carolina on the charge of common law misconduct in office.Â  The McBee
  Chief of Police was also indicted on the same offense.Â  According to the
  indictment, respondent and the Chief of Police assisted certain persons charged
  with crimes in avoiding prosecution by coercing them to surrender money and
  property to the Town of McBee in exchange for having criminal charges against
  them dismissed.Â  On June 16, 2006, the Court placed respondent on interim
  suspension.Â   
On March 30, 2007, respondent pled
  guilty to the indicted offense and was sentenced to five (5) years
  imprisonment, suspended to ninety (90) days incarceration and three (3) years
  of probation. Â On June 27, 2007, respondent tendered his resignation as
  municipal court judge for the towns of McBee, Bethune, and Lynchburg.Â   
LAW
By his misconduct, respondent admits he
  has violated the following Canons of the Code of Judicial Conduct, Rule 501,
  SCACR:Â  Canon 1 (judge shall uphold the integrity of the judiciary); Canon 1A
  (judge should participate in establishing, maintaining, and enforcing high
  standards of conduct and shall personally observe those standards so that the
  integrity and independence of the judiciary will be preserved); Canon 2 (judge
  shall avoid impropriety and appearance of impropriety in all activities); Canon
  2(A) (judge shall respect and comply with the law and shall act at all times in
  a manner that promotes public confidence in the integrity and impartiality of
  the judiciary); Canon 3 (judge shall
    perform duties of judicial office impartially); and Canon 3B(2) (judge shall be
    faithful to the law).Â  Respondent also admits he has violated Rule 7(a)(1) (it
    shall be ground for discipline for judge to violate the Code of Judicial
    Conduct), Rule 7(a)(3) (it shall be ground for discipline for judge to be
    convicted of a crime of moral turpitude or a serious crime), and Rule 7(a)(9)
    (it shall be ground for discipline for judge to violate the Oath of Office) of
    the Rules for Judicial Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 502, SCACR.Â   
CONCLUSION 
	
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by
  Consent and issue a public reprimand.Â  Respondent shall neither seek nor accept
  any judicial position in this State without the prior written authorization of
  this Court after due service on ODC of any petition
  seeking the Courtâ€™s authorization.Â  Respondent is hereby reprimanded for
  his misconduct.Â   
PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and
  PLEICONES, JJ., concur.Â  BEATTY, J., not participating.
  

[1] While this matter was pending, respondent resigned as
  municipal court judge for the towns of McBee, Bethune, and Lynchburg.Â 
  Accordingly, a public reprimand is the most severe sanction the Court can
  impose when a judge no longer holds judicial office.Â  See In re
    Oâ€™Kelley, 361 S.C. 30, 603 S.E.2d 410 (2004); In re Gravely, 321
  S.C. 235, 467 S.E.2d 924 (1996).

title: State v. Rye
description: In this appeal in a criminal case, the Court reversed Appellantâ€™s convictions because the trial court gave an incomplete jury charge on a requested affirmative defense.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        
		v.
        Grover Rye, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Richland County
  Â James W. Johnson, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge

Opinion No. 26379
  Heard May 3, 2007 - Filed September 10,
  2007

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
        Katherine
          Carruth Link, of West Columbia, and Kenneth M. Mathews, of Columbia, for
          Appellant.
        Attorney
          General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
          Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, and Solicitor Warren Blair Giese, all
          of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF
  JUSTICE TOAL:Â  This is a direct appeal in a criminal case.Â  A jury
  convicted Appellant Grover Rye (â€œAppellantâ€) of murder, and we certified the
  case for review from the court of appeals.Â  Because we find that the jury was
  not properly charged regarding a defense Appellant asserted at trial, we
  reverse.
Factual/Procedural
  Background
The
  events which culminated in the incident that is the subject of this appeal are
  both disturbing and bizarre.Â  According to the record, Appellant owned a parcel
  of property on which he stored tools and equipment he used in his business. Â Although
  this property was not Appellantâ€™s primary residence, he occasionally slept in a
  house located on the property.Â  Appellant visited the property every day, and
  sometimes more than once a day, to maintain the property and to feed several pet
  cats Appellant kept there.Â   
Between
  March and August 2004, Appellant experienced continuous problems with
  trespassers on his property.Â  According to the record, these trespassers not
  only entered Appellantâ€™s property, damaged the premises, and stole Appellantâ€™s
  equipment, the trespassers also made a sport of shooting (and killing) Appellantâ€™s
  pet cats.Â  According to Appellant, he phoned the police on several separate
  occasions after discovering that trespassers had been on his property, but he
  was told that the police â€œdid not need to respond to cat-killing reports.â€
According
  to the record, one of the primary trespassers was Appellantâ€™s neighbor.Â  On the
  day of the incident which is the subject of the instant case, the neighbor, a
  friend, and the deceased (an off-duty county police deputy), took firearms onto

    as near as you can to put yourself in defendantâ€™s situation at the time he
    [fired the fatal shot].Â  You should consider the circumstances by which he was
    surrounded, and take into consideration the person with whom he was dealing,
    and all of the facts which surrounded him, as you obtained the same from the
    testimony, and as near as you can, view the situation from defendantâ€™s
    standpoint.Â  Unless the state shows that a person of ordinary reason, coolness
    and prudence would not have acted as defendant did under the circumstances that
    surrounded him at the time the fatal [shot was fired] then you should find the
    defendant not guilty.

The trial court refused to
  charge the proposed charge because the court believed it had adequately covered
  the law.
A request to charge
  a correct statement of the law on an issue raised by the indictment and the
  evidence presented at trial should not be refused.Â  State v. Austin, 299
  S.C. 456, 385 S.E.2d 830 (1989).Â  However, if the trial court refuses to give a
  specific charge, there is no error if the charge actually given sufficiently
  covers the substance of the request.Â  Id.
Although
  appellantâ€™s proposed charge on appearances was a correct statement of the law,[4] it was unnecessary for the trial court to use the proposed charge when his
  charge to the jury adequately covered the contents of the proposed charge.Â 
  Besides the specific appearances charge the court issued, the court also
  charged the jury the following:

  If the defendant was actually in imminent danger, it
    must be shown that the circumstances would have warranted a person of ordinary
    firmness and courage to strike the fatal blow to prevent death or serious
    bodily injury.Â  If the defendant believed that he was in imminent danger of
    death or serious bodily injury, it must be shown that a reasonably prudent
    person of ordinary firmness and courage would have had the same belief.
  In
    deciding whether the defendant actually was or believed that he was in imminent
    danger of death or serious bodily injury, you should consider all the facts and
    circumstances surrounding the crime, including the physical condition and
    characteristics of the defendant and the victim.
  The
    defendant does not have to show that he was actually in danger.Â  It is enough
    that the defendant believed he was in imminent danger and a reasonable and
    prudent person of ordinary reason and ordinary firmness and courage would have
    had the same belief.

Accordingly, I would find the
  trial court did not err by refusing to give appellantâ€™s proposed charge on
  appearances.Â  See State v. Burkhart, 350 S.C. 252, 565 S.E.2d 298
  (2002) (failure to give requested jury instruction is not prejudicial error
  where the instructions given afford the proper test for determining the
  issues); State v. Hughey, 339 S.C. 439, 529 S.E.2d 721, cert. denied,
  531 U.S. 946 (2000) (trial courtâ€™s refusal to provide specific jury
  instructions is not reversible error if the general instructions are
  sufficiently broad to enable the jury to understand the law and the issues
  involved).
CONCLUSION
Whether appellant
  was actually acting in self-defense or in defense of his habitation were
  questions for the jury.Â  Therefore, I would find the trial court properly
  denied the motions for directed verdict and that the trial court did not err by
  refusing to charge appellantâ€™s proposed instructions to the jury.Â  Further, I
  would affirm appellantâ€™s remaining issues pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR,
  and the following authorities:Â  Issue 4:Â  State v. Gaster, Â 349 S.C.
  545, 564 S.E.2d 87 (2002) (the admission or exclusion of evidence is a matter addressed to the sound discretion of the trial court and its ruling will not be disturbed in the
  absence of a manifest abuse of discretion accompanied by probable prejudice); Clark v.
  Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 529 S.E.2d 528 (2000) (trial judge has broad discretion in determining whether to admit
  demonstrative evidence including charts and diagrams which are not direct evidence and have only secondary relevance); State v. McAlister, 149 S.C. 367, 147 S.E. 310 (1929)
  (admission of an inaccurate crime scene diagram not in error where judge
  informed jury it was not drawn to scale and informed jury it was admissible for
  the purpose of explaining a witnessâ€™ testimony regarding landmarks); Issue 5:Â  State v. Tucker, 319 S.C. 425, 462 S.E.2d 263 (1995), cert. denied,
  516 U.S. 1080 (1996) (admission of evidence is within trial courtâ€™s discretion
  and absent abuse of discretion, it will not be reversed on appeal); Issue 6:Â  State v. Shuler, 344 S.C. 604, 545 S.E.2d 805, cert. denied, 534
  U.S. 977 (2001) (improper vouching occurs when the prosecution places the
  governmentâ€™s prestige behind a witness by making explicit personal assurances
  of a witnessâ€™ veracity, or where a prosecutor implicitly vouches for a witnessâ€™
  veracity by indicating information not presented to the jury supports the
  testimony); Issue 7:Â  State v. Bryant, 372 S.C. 305, 642
  S.E.2d 582 (2007) (defendants making a claim under Brady must
  demonstrate that (1) the evidence was favorable to the defense; (2) it was in
  the possession of or known to the prosecution; (3) it was suppressed by the
  prosecution; and (4) it was material to guilt or punishment); Issue 8:Â  State
  v. Johnson, 334 S.C. 78, 512 S.E.2d 795 (1999) (to qualify for reversal on
  ground of cumulative effect of trial errors, defendant must demonstrate errors
  adversely affected his right to fair trial).
I further find no
  merit to the Stateâ€™s Issue requesting the dismissal of the appeal for failure
  to timely serve the Notice of Appeal.Â  Pursuant to Rule 233(b), SCACR, the
  service was properly made by mailing to the solicitor at his last known
  address.
Acting Justice E. C. BURNETT, III,
  concurs.

[1] This implication arises from one of the elements of the defense of
  self-defense.Â  As our precedent recognizes, self-defense requires that a
  defendant show that (1) he was without fault in bringing on the difficulty; (2)
  he was in actual imminent danger of losing his life or sustaining serious
  bodily injury, or he must have actually believed he was in imminent danger of
  losing his life or sustaining serious bodily injury; (3) a reasonably prudent
  person of ordinary firmness and courage would have entertained the same belief;
  and (4) he had no other probable means of avoiding the danger.  State
  v. Bryant, 336 S.C. 340, 344-45, 520 S.E.2d 319, 321-22 (1999).
[2]Appellant
  did not explain how Odomâ€™s rifle ended up six feet from Odomâ€™s body or why the
  rifle was on safety when it was found.
[3]A
  ballistics expert testified, however, that given it is difficult to fully load
  an AR-15, it would not be uncommon for only 38 rounds to be loaded into a
  40-round magazine.
[4]See State v. Rash, 182 S.C. 42, 188 S.E. 435 (1936) (finding this
  charge embodied a sound proposition of law and should have been charged in
  connection with the element of self-defense).

title: State v. Houey
description: The Court affirmed the circuit courtâ€™s order requiring appellant to undergo testing for HIV and Hepatitis B, finding that a showing of probable cause that appellant actually suffered from one of the diseases was not required by the Fourth Amendment or the South Carolina Constitution.  The Court also found the statute constitutional in light of appellantâ€™s challenge that the statute is vague.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Ronte Houey, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Cherokee County
Â J. Mark Hayes, II, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26381
Heard June 5, 2007 - Filed September 10, 2007 

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Thomas E. Shealy, of Gaffney, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Senior Assistant Attorney General Norman Mark Rapoport, all of Columbia, and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
			
		
	

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  Ronte Houey (Appellant) was charged with second-degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor (CSCM).Â  The solicitor moved pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-740(B) (2003) for an order requiring Appellant to submit to testing for HIV and other diseases.Â  The circuit court ordered the testing, and we affirm.
FACTS
After Appellant was arrested and charged with second-degree CSCM, Â Â the solicitor, at the request of the victimâ€™s legal guardian, moved for an order requiring Appellant to submit to HIV and other STD testing pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-740(B).[1]Â  Appellant opposed the motion, arguing the State must first demonstrate probable cause that Appellant actually carries the disease before testing may be ordered.Â  He claimed the failure of Â§ 16-3-740(B) to require such a probable cause determination resulted in an unconstitutional invasion of his privacy.Â  Appellant also argued the statute was unconstitutionally vague.
The circuit court issued an order requiring Appellant to be tested, finding any alleged constitutional violations were irrelevant in light of the Stateâ€™s stipulation that it would not use the test results during trial.Â  The circuit court also found that testing ordered pursuant to Â§ 16-3-740(B) did not violate Appellantâ€™s constitutional rights.
ISSUES
1.  Does S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-740(B) require the State to establish probable cause that a suspect is actually infected with a disease before testing may be ordered?
2.  Is S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-740(B) unconstitutionally vague?
1. Â Â Â Â Â  PROBABLE CAUSE
Appellant asserts Â§ 16-3-740(B) permits a search of an individualâ€™s bodily fluids without a probable cause determination the defendant is actually infected.Â  As such, he argues it violates Fourth Amendment guarantees against unreasonable searches and seizures, as well as Article I, section 10 of the South Carolina Constitution.Â  We disagree.[2]

	Section 16-3-740(B) provides:
	(B) Upon the request of a victim who has been exposed to body fluids during the commission of a criminal offense, or upon the request of the legal guardian of a victim who has been exposed to body fluids during the commission of a criminal offense, the solicitor must, at any time after the offender is charged, or at any time after a petition has been filed against an offender in family court, petition the court to have the offender tested for Hepatitis B and HIV.Â  An offender must not be tested under this section for Hepatitis B and HIV without a court order.Â  To obtain a court order, the solicitor must demonstrate the following:
	(1) the victim or the victimâ€™s legal guardian requested the tests;
	(2) there is probable cause that the offender committed the offense;
	(3) there is probable cause that during the commission of the offense there was a risk that body fluids were transmitted from one person to another; and
	(4) the offender has received notice of the petition and notice of his right to have counsel represent him at a hearing.
	The results of the tests must be kept confidential and disclosed only to the solicitor who obtained the court order.Â  The solicitor shall then notify only those persons designated in subsection (C).Â  
	

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-740(B).
The State concedes the testing of blood is a search within the ambit of the Fourth Amendment.Â  See Skinner v. Ry. Lab. Exec., 489 U.S. 602, 617 (1989); State v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 53, 625 S.E.2d 216, 222 (2006).Â  However, the United States Supreme Court has used a special needs analysis, rather than a traditional probable cause inquiry, in cases where testing of bodily fluids was sought not as part of a criminal investigation, but rather to promote other important state interests.[3]
The special needs exception allows a search unsupported by probable cause when special needs, beyond the normal need for law enforcement, make the warrant and probable cause requirements of the Fourth Amendment impracticable.Â  Skinner, supra at 619.Â  In â€œspecial needsâ€ cases, where the object of the search is not to discover evidence to be used at a criminal trial, the Stateâ€™s need to search must be balanced against the invasion occasioned by the search, and the search will be reasonable if the Stateâ€™s interest outweighs the interest of the individual. Â Adams v. State, 498 S.E.2d 268, 271 (Ga. 1998) (citing Skinner, supra at 619).
We must first determine whether a special need exists which allows the State to test an offender pursuant to Â§ 16-3-740(B).Â  We find that the State has a valid interest in protecting the health and safety of victims.Â  Moreover, since Â§ 16-3-740(C) requires counseling for the offender and counseling for the victim at the victimâ€™s request, the statute furthers the Stateâ€™s interest in stemming the spread of HIV and Hepatitis B through education and counseling.Â  As stated by the Illinois Supreme Court:

	There are few, if any, interests more essential to a stable society than the health and safety of its members.Â  Toward that end, the State has a compelling interest in protecting and promoting public health and, here, in adopting measures reasonably designed to prevent the spread of AIDSâ€¦.Once persons who are carriers of the virus have been identified, the victims of their conduct and the offenders themselves can receive necessary treatment, and, moreover, can adjust their conduct so that other members of the public do not also become exposed to HIV.Â  In this way, the spread of AIDS through the community can be slowed, if not halted.Â  We believe that the HIV testing requirement advances a special governmental need.

People v. Adams, 597 N.E.2d 574, 580-581 (Ill. 1992) (cited in Adams v. State, supra).
In relation to Appellantâ€™s privacy interest, the Fourth Amendment permits minor intrusions by the State into an individualâ€™s body under stringently limited conditions.Â  State v. Allen, 277 S.C. 595, 597, 291 S.E.2d 459, 460 (1982).Â  Although Â§ 16-3-740(B) does not specify how the offender should be tested, the statute has a provision for additional testing by blood, saliva, and head or pubic hair.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-740(F).Â  Regardless of the manner tested pursuant to this section, Appellant has a nominal privacy interest in being free from HIV and Hepatitis B testing, even where such minimally invasive testing is done only for health reasons outside the context of a criminal investigation.
Where the privacy interests implicated by the search are minimal, and where an important non-criminal governmental interest furthered by the intrusion would be placed in jeopardy by a requirement of individualized suspicion, a search may be reasonable despite the absence of such suspicion.Â  Skinner, supra at 624.Â  Such is the case here.Â  The Stateâ€™s interest in these cases would be jeopardized by requiring individualized suspicion because it would be nearly impossible to show probable cause that an offender suffers from HIV or Hepatitis B, since neither disease usually manifests clear outward symptoms.Â  Thus, the statute does not violate the Fourth Amendment by failing to require probable cause that the offender has HIV or Hepatitis B before a court may order testing pursuant to Â§ 16-3-740(B).
While the Fourth Amendment does not require probable cause and a warrant where special needs exist, our legislature has acted to provide extra protection.Â  Under Â§ 16-3-740(B), both probable cause AND a court order are required before an offender may be tested.Â  Our holding today that the special needs exception applies to the issue of particularized suspicion does not render these statutory prerequisites impracticable or unnecessary. 
 
Appellantâ€™s argument that Â§16-3-740(B) is unconstitutional under the South Carolina Constitution also fails.Â  Although our constitution favors a higher level of privacy protection than the Fourth Amendment, State v. Forrester, 343 S.C. 637, 541 S.E.2d 837 (2001), the testing at issue here is not overly intrusive or so unreasonable as to render the statute violative of the South Carolina Constitution.
Accordingly, we hold that probable cause based on individualized suspicion that an offender carries HIV or Hepatitis B is not required by the Fourth Amendment of the United States Constitution or by Article I, section 10, of the South Carolina Constitution.
2.Â Â Â Â Â Â  VAGUENESS
Appellant also contends Â§ 16-3-740(B) is unconstitutionally vague, inasmuch as it allows testing without regard to the timing of an alleged crime.Â  Appellantâ€™s argues that since there is no requirement of immediate testing of a suspect, any test result may not necessarily be indicative of the suspectâ€™s condition at the time of the alleged assault.Â  We disagree.
The void-for-vagueness doctrine rests on the constitutional principle that procedural due process requires fair notice and proper standards for adjudication. Â Peterson Outdoor Advert. v. City of Myrtle Beach, 327 S.C. 230, 236, 489 S.E.2d 630, 633 (1997).Â  As to civil standards, there appears a less stringent test than that applied in criminal contexts.Â  See Village of Hoffman Est., 455 U.S. 489, 498-499 (1982) (stating criminal statutes, in general, face a higher vagueness standard than do civil statutes because the consequences of imprecision in the latter are qualitatively less severe).
Appellantâ€™s arguments regarding the timing of testing address evidentiary concerns in the context of the criminal proceeding.Â  Appellantâ€™s concerns are not relevant in light of the Stateâ€™s interest in preventing the spread of HIV and Hepatitis B and the Stateâ€™s interest in protecting the health of alleged victims.Â  These interests are advanced regardless of the time of testing.Â  Accordingly, we find no constitutional violation due to vagueness.
CONCLUSION
We hold that the State need not show probable cause that an offender has a disease before testing may be ordered pursuant to Â§ 16-3-740(B), provided the statutory requirements have been met.Â  In addition, Â§ 16-3-740(B) is not unconstitutionally vague.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s order is
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., and Acting Justice E. C. BURNETT, III, concur. WALLER, J., concurring in result only in a separate opinion in which MOORE, J., concurs. 


JUSTICE WALLER:Â  :Â  I concur in result with the majority opinion, but write separately in adherence to my opinion, as originally written, which is as follows: Â 
Appellant, Ronte Houey, was indicted in November 2005 for criminal sexual conduct (CSC) in the second degree with a minor.Â  The solicitor moved pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-740(B) (2003) for an order requiring Houey to submit to testing for HIV[4] and other sexually transmitted diseases (STD).Â  Houey appeals the order, contending both that Â§ 16-3-740 is unconstitutionally vague, and that the state has no legitimate public health interest in requiring him to be tested for HIV or other diseases.Â  We disagree and affirm.Â  Â Â 
FACTS
Houey was arrested and charged with second-degree CSC for having had sexual intercourse in August 2005, with a girl who was thirteen years old; Houey was twenty years old at the time.Â  Thereafter, at the request of the Victimâ€™s legal guardian, the solicitor moved for an order requiring Houey to submit to HIV and other sexually transmitted disease testing pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-740(B).Â  Houey opposed the motion, contending the state must first demonstrate probable cause Houey actually carried a sexually transmitted disease or was HIV positive before testing could be ordered.Â  He contended the failure of Â§ 16-3-740(B) to require such a probable cause determination resulted in an unconstitutional invasion of his privacy.Â  He also contended the statute was impermissibly vague.Â 
 
The circuit court issued an order requiring Houey to be tested, finding any alleged constitutional violations were irrelevant in light of the stateâ€™s stipulation that it would not use the test results during trial.Â  Houey appealed;Â Â  while the appeal was pending, however, Houey was tried and acquitted of the offense with which he was charged.Â  Accordingly, he has not been tested.Â 
 
ISSUES
1.Â  Does S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-740(B) require the state to establish probable cause that a suspect is actually infected with a sexually transmitted disease before testing may be ordered?
2.Â  Is S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-740(B) unconstitutionally vague?
1.Â  PROBABLE CAUSE
Houey asserts S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-740 unconstitutionally permits a search of an individualâ€™s body fluids without a probable cause determination the defendant is infected with HIV or STDâ€™s.Â  As such, he contends it violates Fourth Amendment guarantees against unreasonable searches and seizures.Â  U.S. Const. amend. IV; S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 10.Â Â  We disagree.

	S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-740 (B) provides, in pertinent part:
	(B) Upon the request of a victim who has been exposed to body fluids during the commission of a criminal offense, or upon the request of the legal guardian of a victim who has been exposed to body fluids during the commission of a criminal offense, the solicitor must, at any time after the offender is charged, or at any time after a petition has been filed against an offender in family court, petition the court to have the offender tested for Hepatitis B and HIV. An offender must not be tested under this section for Hepatitis B and HIV without a court order. To obtain a court order, the solicitor must demonstrate the following:
	(1) the victim or the victimâ€™s legal guardian requested the tests;
	(2) there is probable cause that the offender committed the offense;
	(3) there is probable cause that during the commission of the offense there was a risk that body fluids were transmitted from one person to another; and
	(4) the offender has received notice of the petition and notice of his right to have counsel represent him at a hearing.
	The results of the tests must be kept confidential and disclosed only to the solicitor who obtained the court order. The solicitor shall then notify only those persons designated in subsection (C).Â Â Â Â Â Â  
	

Initially, we agree with the circuit court that given the stateâ€™s agreement it would not use the test results against Houey, any Fourth Amendment violation is harmless.Â  See State v. Forrester, 343 S.C. 637, 643, 541 S.E.2d 837, 840 (2001) (evidence obtained in violation of the Fourth Amendment is inadmissible in both state and federal court). Â Â Â  In any event, we find no Fourth Amendment violation.Â Â  
 
The state concedes the testing of blood for HIV or STDâ€™s is a search within the meaning of the Fourth Amendment.Â  See State v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 625 S.E.2d 216 (2006).Â  See also Chandler v. Miller, 520 U.S. 1295 (1997); Skinner v. Ry. Labor Executives, 489 U.S. 602 (1989); Schmerber v. California, 384 U.S. 757 (1966).Â  When such a search is conducted in furtherance of criminal investigation, the balance is tipped in favor of the defendant and the search â€œis not reasonable unless it is accomplished pursuant to a judicial warrant issued upon probable cause.â€Â  Skinner, 489 U.S. at 624.Â  However, an exception to the warrant clause may apply when â€œspecial needs, beyond the normal need for law enforcement, make the warrant and probable-cause requirement impracticable.â€Â  Id.Â  In Skinner, the U.S. Supreme Court held that where the privacy interests implicated by a search are minimal, and where an important governmental interest furthered by an intrusion would be placed in jeopardy by a requirement of individualized suspicion, a search may be reasonable despite the absence of such suspicion.Â  Id.Â  
 
As noted by the New Jersey Supreme Court in State in Interest of J.G., 701 A.2d 1260, 1266 (N.J. 1997), 
 

	Recently, the Supreme Court has used a special needs analysis in cases where body searches were not conducted to further a criminal investigation, but rather, were alleged to promote other important state interests. 
	See Chandler, 520 U.S. at 1295 (applying special needs analysis to Georgia statute requiring drug tests of candidates for state office); 
	Vernonia School Dist. 47J v. Acton, 515 U.S. 646 (1995) (applying special needs analysis to requirement that student athletes be tested for drug use); 
	Von Raab, 489 U.S. at 656 (applying special needs analysis to United States Customs Service employee drug testing program); 
	Skinner, 489 U.S. at 602 (applying special needs analysis to Federal Railroad Administration employee drug testing program); 
	see also Stigile v. Clinton, 110 F.3d 801 (D.C.Cir. 1997) (applying special needs analysis to Office of Management and Budgetâ€™s random drug testing program);
	Tanks v. Greater Cleveland Regâ€™l Transit Auth., 930 F.2d 475 (6th Cir. 1991) (applying special needs analysis to suspicionless drug testing of bus driver);
	Transport Workersâ€™ Union of Philadelphia, Local 234 v. SEPTA, 884 F.2d 709 (3d Cir. 1989) (applying special needs analysis to SEPTAâ€™s drug testing program).

The Interest of J.G court found HIV testing of accused sex offenders ranks among the limited circumstances in which suspicionless searches are warranted, noting that â€œthe warrant and individualized suspicion requirements are impractical in this context. . . HIV infected sexual offenders often have no outward manifestations of infection, which means that probable cause or individualized suspicion that an assailant is infected with the AIDS virus could not be found without testing. . . .Â  Requiring probable cause or individualized suspicion before testing could be conducted would create the proverbial Catch-22 and would frustrate the governmental purpose behind the search.â€Â  701 A.2d at 1267 (Internal citations omitted).Â  See also State v. Wallace, 2005 WL 940029 (Ohio App. 2 Dist. 2005) (statute authorizing warrantless testing for STDâ€™s upon indictment for enumerated sex offenses did not violate right of privacy, due process or right to be free from unreasonable search and seizure).
We find S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-740 does not effect an unconstitutional invasion of Houeyâ€™s privacy.Â  The test may be ordered only if 1) the victim or a guardian requests it, 2) there is probable cause to believe the defendant committed the offense, and 3) there is probable cause to believe there is a risk bodily fluids may have been transferred from the defendant to the victim.Â  Further, dissemination of the results of any such testing is extremely limited.Â  Given the interests of the victim in ascertaining whether the alleged assailant is HIV positive, we find the statute sufficiently complies with the special needs analysis set forth by the United States Supreme Court in Skinner and Chandler.Â  
 
2.Â  VAGUENESS
Houey also contends S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-740 is impermissibly vague, inasmuch as it allows testing without regard to the timing of an assault.Â  Houeyâ€™s contention is essentially that, since there is no requirement of immediate testing of a suspect, any test result may not necessarily be indicative of the suspectâ€™s condition at the time of the alleged assault.Â Â  We find no constitutional violation.
Generally, the void-for-vagueness doctrine requires that a penal statute define the criminal offense with sufficient definiteness that ordinary people can understand what conduct is prohibited and in a manner that does not encourage arbitrary and discriminatory enforcement. Village of Hoffman Estates v. Flipside, 455 U.S. 489 (1982).Â  As to civil standards, there appears a less stringent test than that applied in criminal contexts.Â  See Village of Hoffman Estates v. Flipside, 455 U.S. 489, 498 (1982) (criminal statutes, in general, face a higher vagueness standard than do civil statutes because the consequences of imprecision are qualitatively less severe); In re Guardianship of Carlsmith, 151 P.3d 717 (Hawaii 2007) (when a statute is not concerned with criminal conduct or first amendment considerations, the court must be fairly lenient in evaluating a claim of vagueness.Â  A civil statute must be so vague and indefinite as really to be no rule or standard at all.Â  Uncertainty is not enough for statute to be unconstitutionally vague; rather, it must be substantially incomprehensible). 
 
A statute can be impermissibly vague for either of two independent reasons.Â  First, it may fail to provide people of ordinary intelligence a reasonable opportunity to understand what conduct it prohibits. Â Or, second, it may authorize or encourage arbitrary and discriminatory enforcement.Â  Hill v. Colorado, 530 U.S. 703, 732 (2000); State v. Thompkins, 263 S.C. 472, 211 S.E.2d 549 (1975).Â  See also In re Amir X.S., 371 S.C. 380,Â  391, 639 S.E.2d 144, 150 (2006) (concept of vagueness or indefiniteness rests on the constitutional principle that procedural due process requires fair notice and proper standards for adjudication); Curtis v. State, 345 S.C.. 557, 549 S.E.2d 591 (2001). 
 
Under the facts of this case, due to the relatively brief period of time between the alleged assault (August 2, 2005), and the date on which the state sought testing (October 27, 2005), we find no constitutional violation.
AFFIRMED.
MOORE, J., concurs.

[1] Despite the caption which implies sexually transmitted diseases are included, Â§ 16-3-740(B) only allows for petitions for court orders to have an offender tested for Hepatitis B and HIV.
[2] Initially, we find the circuit erred by holding any potential constitutional violation would be harmless given the Stateâ€™s agreement not to use the test results against Appellant. Â The agreement is irrelevant because Â§ 16-3-740(I) precludes admission of test results gathered pursuant to subsection (B) in the offenderâ€™s criminal trial.Â  Nonetheless, we do not believe the testing violated Appellantâ€™s constitutional rights.
[3] See Chandler v. Miller, 520 U.S. 305 (1997) (analyzing Georgia statute requiring drug tests of candidates for state office); Vernonia Sch. Dist. 47J v. Acton, 515 U.S. 646 (1995) (analyzing school districtâ€™s requirement that student athletes be tested for drug use); Natl. Treas. Employees Union v. Von Raab, 489 U.S. 656 (1989) (analyzing United States Customs Service employee drug testing program); and Skinner, supra (analyzing Federal Railroad Administration employee drug testing program).
